awd_titl_txt: CNS Core: Small: MAC Layer Failure Control and Avoidance in Cognitive Radio Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Cognitive radio has recently emerged as a promising technology to overcome the imbalance between the increase in spectrum access demand and the inefficiency in spectrum usage by allowing dynamic spectrum access. However, a fundamentally unexplored issue in cognitive radio networking design is how to avoid and control the failures at the medium access control (MAC) layer during spectrum access. This issue is becoming a serious barrier to the success of cognitive radio networks (CRNs). The potential MAC layer failures during spectrum access are unique in CRNs. They will significantly degrade the network performance and sometimes may even block the whole network's operation. Currently, no existing work addresses how to avoid the MAC layer failures or how to mitigate the effect on performance degradation caused by the failures in CRNs. This research is potentially transformative as it will help generate innovative techniques to numerous applications of the CRN technology, e.g., public safety networks, emergency networks, health monitoring, and cognitive mesh networks. It will also have significant impacts on research in emerging technologies with dynamic spectrum access, such as vehicular networks, mobile health, and opportunistic interconnections of heterogeneous wireless networks. The proposed MAC layer designs can also be applied to systems of Internet-of-Things (IoT) with low-power, low-cost IoT devices dynamically accessing the wide spectrum. 

The research objective of this proposal is to design, analyze, and evaluate new MAC layer failure control and avoidance protocols for cognitive radio networks (CRNs) without a common control channel. The proposed MAC layer designs aim at minimizing the failure rate caused by various factors during spectrum access and minimizing the average spectrum access delay. This research is the first that systematically addresses the unique failures at the MAC layer during spectrum access in CRNs under practical scenarios. This project includes three major research tasks: (1) rendezvous congestion control to avoid network congestion and to speed up the rendezvous; (2) handshake failure avoidance to avoid synchronous deadlocks and to derive the optimal size of a time slot for handshake; and (3) transmission failure mitigation to adapt the optimal frame size and to maximize the overall throughput. This research will offer a complimentary yet fundamental building block to existing CRN MAC research. This project also integrates research findings into related graduate courses and diversity support.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Cognitive radio has recently emerged as a promising technology to overcome the imbalance between the increase in spectrum access demand and the inefficiency in spectrum usage by allowing dynamic spectrum access. A “cognitive radio” is a radio that can change its transmitter parameters based on interactions with the environment in which it operates. Learning and adaptation are the two distinct features of a cognitive radio transceiver. A significant amount of research work has addressed various issues in cognitive radio networks (CRNs). However, a fundamentally unexplored issue in CRN networking design is how to avoid and control the failures at the Medium Access Control (MAC) layer during spectrum access. This issue is becoming a serious barrier to the success of CRNs.

 

The research objective of this proposal is to design, analyze, and evaluate new MAC layer failure control and avoidance protocols for cognitive radio networks (CRNs). The proposed MAC layer designs aim at minimizing the failure rate caused by various factors during spectrum access and minimizing the average access delay. The approach involves identifying and modeling all the possible failures in CRN MAC caused by the changing spectrum environment, examining practical scenarios for the MAC layer design, proactively utilizing the information learned from the time-varying network environment for intelligent design of fully distributed MAC-layer protocols, and optimizing the performance via spectrum-adaptive design.

 

This research systematically addresses the unique failures at the MAC layer during spectrum access in CRNs under practical scenarios. It focuses on minimizing the MAC layer failure rate, mitigating the effects caused by failures and at the same time, accelerating the spectrum access in CRNs. This project includes three major research tasks: (1) rendezvous control design: model and analyze the factors causing the channel status change during rendezvous, design rendezvous delay compensation to speed up the rendezvous, and design rendezvous congestion control to avoid network congestion; (2) handshake guarantee design: analyze the factors causing the handshake failure, design a contention window mechanism to avoid synchronous deadlocks, and derive the optimal size of a time slot for handshake; and (3) packet fragmentation design to mitigate the effect of transmission failures: model the probability of frame retransmission resulting from a spectrum handoff and design a self-adaptive optimal fragmentation protocol to maximize the network throughput.

 

This research is potentially transformative as it helps generate innovative techniques to numerous applications of the CRN technology, e.g., public safety networks, emergency networks, health monitoring, home networking, and cognitive mesh networks. It also has significant impacts on research in emerging technologies with dynamic spectrum access, such as vehicular networks, mobile health, and opportunistic interconnections of heterogeneous wireless networks. The proposed MAC layer designs can also be applied to systems of Internet-of-Things (IoT) with low-power, low-cost IoT devices dynamically accessing the wide spectrum.

 

This project provided excellent opportunities for graduate and undergraduate research students to gain valuable educational training and research experiences. Three PhD students have participated in this research. Results from this research are presented at IEEE journals and international conferences. Topics on CRNs with ample inputs from the research work are incorporated into the graduate-level courses taught at UNC Charlotte. The synergy between the topics covered in the courses and the research results in this project mutually benefits both. The PI also worked closely with various programs encouraging students from under-represented groups to participate in research activities.
